awd_titl_txt: RCN:  Intermittent River Research Coordination Network (IRRCN): Integrating Intermittent River Ecology and Hydrology
awd_abstract_narration:
Life is simply different in the absence of water, especially for life in rivers and streams. Yet half of the Earth's rivers dry or stop flowing each year. These streams or rivers are called "intermittent." Intermittent rivers are not well studied or understood by researchers studying river ecology or river hydrology. Initial research shows the hydrology and ecology of intermittent rivers are very different from rivers that always flow. The current scientific understanding and concepts of streams and rivers is incomplete as it is biased towards the half of the Earth's rivers that continuously flow. The Intermittent River Research Coordination Network (IR-RCN) will organize a series of expert workgroups that will synthesize the growing body of research on intermittent river hydrology and ecology. These workgroups will produce generalized frameworks that can explain how intermittent river hydrologic and ecologic systems work. This research is important because intermittent rivers are often overlooked or excluded from water management plans due to uncertainty about their hydrologic and ecological importance. Graduate students will receive interdisciplinary training in hydrology and ecology and network with intermittent river ecologists and hydrologists across the globe.

Funds will be provided by this award to form three workgroups on intermittent river hydrology, ecology, and ecohydrology. The hydrology workgroup will seek to generate new tools to characterize intermittent river flow regimes, develop a hierarchical scale-based framework for predicting spatial intermittence patterns, and compare statistical and processed-based models for prediction of intermittent river streamflow metrics. The ecology workgroup will synthesize large scale intermittent river biodiversity and ecosystem datasets to better understand the structure and function of intermittent river ecosystems. The ecohydrology workgroup will integrate products from the ecology and hydrology workgroups to identify hydrologic controls on intermittent river ecosystems and integrate these findings into our current river conceptual frameworks designed for rivers that always flow. The IR-RCN will improve the management of intermittent rivers by enhancing communication and networking among academic researchers and nonacademic stakeholders, including government agencies and NGOs. Datasets, methods, materials and projects produced by the IR-RCN will be made open access on the IR-RCN web portal and deposited in the Dryad Digital Repository for long-term availability, which will broadly impact the global scientific community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Non-perennial rivers and streams dry up periodically and comprise the majority of our global river network lengths. While the characteristics of drying are important for ecosystem function, little communication across scientific disciplines has historically made it challenging to advance our understanding of what drives river drying, where and when it happens, and how it affects ecosystems. This Research Coordination Network brought together over 60 ecologists and hydrologists from across the world in one virtual and three in-person collaborative workshops, and through countless virtual sub-project and pre-workshop meetings, to develop new disciplinary and interdisciplinary understanding of these critically important aquatic systems. 

Intellectual Merit: To advance our understanding of when and where river drying occurs, we analyzed long-term streamflow datasets from the U.S. Geological Survey stream gaging network. We found that drying occurs throughout all regions of the United States, with streams in southern portions becoming drier because of climate change and human modification of our water resources. We used machine learning approaches to identify common patterns and drivers to drying that occur across a wide range of river systems, which we applied to understanding aquatic organism community behavior. And while drying is often the hydrologic focus of these systems, we urged our scientific communities to equally consider the characteristics of wetting to understand how these river types shape our ecosystems. We explored how we as a scientific community measure streamflow and identified both challenges and opportunities for measuring and interpreting low and zero flows. Finally, we showed that globally, our gaging networks are placed disproportionately on large, perennial rivers, which may influence our understanding of the portion of our global water resources that persist in non-perennial systems. 

To advance our understanding of how river drying impacts ecology, we reviewed and synthesized existing literature. We found that most stream ecosystem conceptual models were designed for continuously flowing streams, not those that dry; and that drying can have different impacts on stream ecosystems depending on whether or not the drying event is natural or artificially induced by human activity. We developed new conceptual frameworks for studying the subsurface zone to account for drying and fluctuating groundwater levels that occur in non-perennial streams, and for designing environmental flows in river networks where there is a mix of perennial and non-perennial streams and river reaches. We also synthesized existing datasets of invertebrates and fish in non-perennial stream systems. We found that organisms vary greatly in response to these disturbances, and that this variation can be profound within a group of organisms (e.g. different species of invertebrates) and also between groups of organisms (e.g. invertebrates vs. algae vs. fish). 

In addition to these disciplinary-focused scientific advancements, we conducted a literature review to provide a recommendation for common language that all scientists and natural resource managers should use when describing these systems. We also created a new hydrological-ecological conceptual framework that predicts how different wetting and drying regimes should impact stream biogeochemistry and organismal ecology.

Broader Impacts: Despite being globally abundant and widespread, there is considerable debate in many countries about how, and even whether, non-perennial streams and rivers should be protected and regulated. Our work synthesized and organized existing knowledge of these systems from hydrological and ecological perspectives that will help inform this debate. We created a diverse collaborative network of ecologists in a mix of career stages, ranging from graduate students to senior scientists and full professors. In particular, we focused heavily on supporting and training early career researchers, as evidenced by the fact that ~85% of the 26 of RCN-supported publications had early career researchers as the first author (where early career is defined as a researcher who is still establishing their academic career and has not yet secured a stable position). We generated opportunities for senior network members to mentor more junior members, and all of our junior members successfully graduated or were promoted to higher ranked positions in their respective fields. We also provided training for network members in creating safe and inclusive work environments, and in recruiting and retaining team members from underrepresented groups.
